text: Hi, this is Mrs. Miller.

text: Yes, yes it is.

speaker: Student
text: Hi Mrs Miller, my name is Jackson Agroz. I'm the medical student working at the clinic today. I am calling to speak about your daughter. What was your name again?

speaker: Patient
text: Jackson Agrroz.

speaker: Student
text: Okay. Your S-47024. That's your OSCE number?

speaker: Student
text: Okay, well, OSCENumber21, sorry. There we go, thank you.

speaker: Patient
text: Well, I am glad you called. I was very worried because my daughter has had a cough for a long time, and it just seems it won't go away.

speaker: Student
text: Okay. How long has it been going on for?

speaker: Patient
text: Five weeks is when it started.

speaker: Student
text: Okay, and can you describe the cough to me?

speaker: Patient
text: It's a dry cough that's almost nonstop.

speaker: Student
text: Okay? And you said it's been getting worse over these five weeks?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes. At first it was on and off, but now it is constant.

speaker: Student
text: Okay, has she been vomiting at all?

speaker: Patient
text: No.

speaker: Student
text: Has she has been sick other than the cough? Any fevers, chills, runny nose, anything like that?

speaker: Patient
text: Well, five weeks ago she had had a fever and some nasal congestion and the cough, and it lasted two days. But the coughing is the only thing that didn't go away.

speaker: Student
text: Okay. So was she seen in clinic at that time, or did she seem like her symptoms got better except for the cough?

speaker: Patient
text: It seemed that her systems got worse. Her symptoms went better. Well, the coughing and the head congestion went away.

speaker: Student
text: Do you think she'll need like an antibiotic or something?

speaker: Patient
text: So why don't we, I'll kind of talk you through what I'm thinking of towards the end if you don't mind. I'M just trying to flesh out everything and make sure I don't miss anything. Does that make sense?

speaker: Student
text: Yes. I appreciate your concern, though. I know that it's got to be scary for you.

speaker: Patient
text: Yes

speaker: Student
text: Has she been doing okay in school with the cough or has she just been staying home?

speaker: Patient
text: She's been going to school. She went to the school at the cough, but the last week she stayed out of gym class.

speaker: Student
text: Okay. Is the coughing worse with running or activity or anything like that?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, very, much worse. With the running and the playing with friends.

speaker: Student
text: Okay, has she ever had issues with exercise in the past?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't understand.

speaker: Student
text: Like, for example, when she runs, does she ever have coughing fits or anything like that?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes.

speaker: Student
text: Okay, and that has happened in the last five weeks? Or just these past five weeks.

speaker: Patient
text: These past five weeks

speaker: Student
text: Okay and since the initial start she hasn't had any more fevers or chills or anything like that?

speaker: Patient
text: No, nothing like that.

speaker: Student
text: Has there been anybody sick around her?

speaker: Patient
text: No one around here has been sick at all.

speaker: Student
text: Before she got sick initially, do you remember if she was, if anybody around had been Sick?

speaker: Patient
text: No. Not that I know of.

speaker: Student
text: Okay. Alright. I'm just going to move on to her past medical history. Has Bailey been ill? Has she been in the past? Does she have any medical conditions, I should say?

speaker: Patient
text: No. No nothing like that. She had like a bout of eczema around two years old. And every once in a while she'll get itchy eyes, nose, throat.

speaker: Student
text: Okay, does she take anything for allergies?

speaker: Patient
text: No.

speaker: Student
text: Okay, any surgeries that she's had in the past?

speaker: Patient
text: No, okay.

speaker: Student
text: And as far as family history goes, has there ever been a history of asthma in the family?

speaker: Patient
text: Her dad has a story of as a child, but not now.

speaker: Student
text: Okay? Okay any family histories of high blood pressure?

speaker: Patient
text: Her dad has a history of asthma as a child, but not now.

speaker: Student
text: Okay. Any family history of high blood pressure, diabetes?

speaker: Patient
text: No. No?

speaker: Student
text: Okay, and does she live at home with you and her father?

speaker: Patient
text: She does. My uncle just, I mean her uncle, my brother just moved in with us about a month ago.

speaker: Student
text: Okay does anybody in the house smoke?

speaker: Patient
text: Only outside.

speaker: Student
text: Okay, and who smokes? Your brother or?

speaker: Patient
text: Yeah, me. My brother and her dad.

speaker: Student
text: Okay and does she have any siblings?

speaker: Patient
text: No.

speaker: Student
text: Okay any pets at home?

speaker: Patient
text: We have a dog and two cats, and they go inside and out.

speaker: Student
text: Okay? And Bailey hasn't ever had any issues with the dog or cats before?

speaker: Patient
text: No, no.

speaker: Student
text: Okay Ms. Miller, so just to kind of, do you mind if I summarize what I've heard of before and just so you can interject if I'm missing anything?

speaker: Patient
text: Okay.

speaker: Student
text: of fever, runny nose. But ever since then, she has this worsening cough that's kind of progressing and now preventing her from doing everything that she wants to do. No past medical history except for some eczema and maybe some runny nose occasionally. And then her father had asthma. Anything else in particular I'm missing?

speaker: Patient
text: No, not that I can think of.

speaker: Student
text: So just to walk you through, Ms. Miller, what I'm thinking, I think it's possible that your daughter might have some asthma. She's, especially the fact that there is some smoke exposure. I know that, I mean, I don't know if you've heard of it, but I do know, I feel that you're family members are smoking outside and that can help lessen her exposure, but still considering that she's got a family history of family history asthma and past medical history those tend to kind of run together with asthma it's not definite that that's this is what she has but I would advise coming in to get further pulmonary workup for her to see if she needs an inhaler or something.

speaker: Patient
text: Okay.

speaker: Student
text: Does that sound agreeable to you? Is that something that you can do to bring her in sometime?

speaker: Patient
text: Yeah. Okay, perfect. Yeah, absolutely. We can try to make an appointment as soon as possible. It's also possible that she could have just had a viral illness, considering her fever and chills and cough. Those also tend to run together. And cough is something that it usually lasts much longer than the other two and can get really irritating. So it's possible this is just a virus. It could be a real illness. But I would rather be safer than sorry and make sure she gets checked out for asthma as well.

speaker: Patient
text: Okay. That's great. I'm really worried about this. I'd like to get it cleared up.

speaker: Student
text: Yeah, absolutely. We can see you as soon as possible.
